description: From Middle English twinclen, twynclen, from Old English twinclian (“to twinkle”), equivalent to twink (“to wink; blink; twinkle”) +‎ -le (frequentative suffix). Compare German zwinkern (“to wink; twinkle”).

entries.meaning: A sparkle or glimmer of light.
examples: Soon the rocket was out of sight, and the flame was only seen as a tiny twinkle of light.

entries.meaning: A sparkle of delight in the eyes.
examples: He was a rotund, jolly man with a twinkle in his eye.
I saw the twinkle of white feet,
The popular Swedish cartoon song about genitals was translated as "Willie and Twinkle".

verbs.description: twinkle (third-person singular simple present twinkles, present participle twinkling, simple past and past participle twinkled)

entries.meaning: (of a source of light) To shine with a flickering light; to glimmer.
examples: We could see the lights of the village twinkling in the distance.

entries.meaning: (chiefly of eyes) To be bright with delight.
examples: His shrewd little eyes twinkled roguishly.

entries.meaning: To bat, blink or wink the eyes.
examples: She smiled and gave a little nod and twinkled her eyes […]
A butterfly twinkled among the vines […]
